comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] It was on again in 1891, this time at the Queen's Theatre. 1892 and it was on the bill at the Gaiety again, but only performed on one night and not given any prominence in the publicity. I can't find anything after that.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: There was a law on the sale of alcohol out of hours including Sundays but not within city limits.  You hace to be a "Bona Fide" traveller on a journey seeking refreshments.  I can't make out where it advertises but the Coachmans Inn at Cloughran which is still going strong was one of the first on the north side.  It was very contentious and the various police forces had great craic enforcing it!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Pigott's Piano advert from March 1890

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Interesting that Betjeman's poem mentions the dissolute Lupin Pooter. In The Diary of a Nobody Charles Pooter (Lupin's father) has this entry for April 15th : As it was getting on for five, we four held a consultation, and Gowing suggested that we should make for “The Cow and Hedge” and get some tea. Stillbrook said: “A brandy-and-soda was good enough for him.” I reminded them that all public-houses were closed till six o’clock. Stillbrook said, “That’s all right—_bona-fide_ travellers.” We arrived; and as I was trying to pass, the man in charge of the gate said: “Where from?” I replied: “Holloway.” He immediately put up his arm, and declined to let me pass. I turned back for a moment, when I saw Stillbrook, closely followed by Cummings and Gowing, make for the entrance. I watched them, and thought I would have a good laugh at their expense, I heard the porter say: “Where from?” When, to my surprise, in fact disgust, Stillbrook replied: “Blackheath,” and the three were immediately admitted. Gowing called to me across the gate, and said: “We shan’t be a minute.” I waited for them the best part of an hour. When they appeared they were all in most excellent spirits, and the only one who made an effort to apologise was Mr. Stillbrook, who said to me: “It was very rough on you to be kept waiting, but we had another spin for S. and B.’s.” I walked home in silence; I couldn’t speak to them. I felt very dull all the evening, but deemed it advisable _not_ to say anything to Carrie about the matter.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Bone Fide ad is on the Blackrock tram, does it say "Stop at Booterstown"?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/30369211@N00] Nice one Niall, being a northsider I was thinking Porterstown but Booterstown is much more likely and is probably the right distance from the post office which was usually the point of reference for distances of that sort.www. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/29809546@N00] Not being familiar with the poem I was at a loss as to what you and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/64555638@N00] were saying, I get the message now!  When the police raided your address decided if you were a "Bona Fide" traveller or not and the publican was obliged to enquire.  Pooter made the mistake of being honest in his reply whereas his friends chose Blackheath which was far enough away to make them legitimate!! (I do get there eventually!)

comment._content: So, the latest date that [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] could find for Arabian Nights at the Gaiety is 1892 and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] has the whole Dublin tram system electrified by 1901, so I'm thinking that we're well off on a date of Circa 1900 on this one... What should we go for? A happy medium between somewhere between 1892 and 1901, or plump for 1892? Or is there some other evidence in this photo that can give us a more definite date? Help!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland]Help is at hand!  Apologies for posting this photo again but it acts as a set reference point with its printed "©1896".  I can't see many differences, so how about "ca.1895" for your picture?  It occurs to me that men started wearing 'boater' straw hats on sunny days towards the C20th and bowlers went out of fashion.  Not many boaters in evidence here.
btw - 'Bona fide Travellers on Sundays' laws also applied in Australia until relatively recently.  Drunk drivers everywhere ... blame the Poms!

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/hwmobs/6811329243/]

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: From Dublin City Public Libraries www.askaboutireland.ie/reading-room/environment-geography... Horse trams - "The three companies, all of which operated on 5' 3" (1.6m) gauge tracks, amalgamated in 1880 to form the Dublin United Tramways Company, with 137 trams running over 32 route miles." "the first electrics reaching Nelson Pillar from Clontarf on 19th March 1898". "The entire system was converted by January 1900, except for the line from Haddington Road to Sandymount, on which the last horse tram ran on 13th January 1901." So this photo has to be between 1880 and 1898. The answer must lie in "first use" of those strange hats the women are wearing.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
I'm changing my vote!

We know it's after 1879 (Gray statue. Blackrock Tram). 40s suit means before 1883.

So I'll vote 1881.

Our 1890 guess was partly based on The Arabian nights review, but the review itself mentions that the play was previously on in Dublin with a better cast.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Improvements to Dame St premises were made in 1899. ... and improved lavatories, on the most improved scientific scale, and furnished with every modern requisite, have been constructed, opening off the several landings on the stair.

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content:
Just been exploring the comments on this site. We're lucky enough in the RIAC Archive to have an almost complete run of The Irish Cyclist up to it's demise in 1929 and also several volumes of The Irish Wheelman which closed in 1903 when JC Percy joined forces with RJ Mecredy. Incidently,  Percy French was a correspondent of both The Irish Cyclist and The Motor News.

I've always contended that if you want to understand early motoring then you must also understand what went before it - ie. cycling in its many forms. The cycling craze was at its height in 1890 when John Boyd Dunlop invented the pneumatic tyre. There were several cycle tracks in Ireland including in the grounds of the RDS, Queens University, Ballymena and, of course, Waterford. Tricycles were also popular and one important make was 'The Dublin Tricycle' invented by Dr. Blood, no less.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Arabian Nights made 'a return visit' at the Gaiety in March 1889. It was on from May to July in May 1888 it was initially on for 6 nights, but extended its run to July 28th, when Freeman's announced The successful farcical comedy, "Arabian Nights", which has attained such popularity with Dublin audiences, will be produced for the last time to-night. I can't find any reviews or adverts for performances before that. When he has a sale on, right into the 1890s, Mr Hyam advertises his suits as 'usually 40s' reduced to 29s 6d, but when there is no sale on, they are 42s. On May 9th suits were 30s. On the same page as the advert for the last night of 'Arabian Nights' at the Gaiety, there is an advert for Hyams sale, where men's suits are "14s 9d, 18s 9d, 22s 9d etc, 30 per cent under usual prices". When the sale was over ion August 27th, suits were "20s, 25s, 30s, 40s and upwards" Make of that what you will!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
O'Connell bridge, as shown, wasn't opened until 1882. Carlisle bridge was narrower, and slightly humped. Hmm, sources differ on that date, so I'll go with the earlier 1880.

The bridge and O'Connell monument from 1880 don't look brand new here (see the tide marks at left) so towards 1890 is looking reasonable again...

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 
Email to me from Victoria and Albert Museum, London.
"Thank you very much for your enquiry, and for forwarding this interesting photograph.

C.Willett Cunnington's English Women's Clothing in the Nineteenth Century  shows that the type of hat seen in your photo, with a high crown and sitting low on the forehead, first appeared in fashion plates in 1885. These hats continued to be seen in plates until around 1887. As fashions would have been worn for a longer period of time than they were illustrated in plates, it is likely that this kind of hat would have been worn through the late 1880s.
I hope that this is of use in dating your photograph.
All best wishes,
Lizzie Bisley.
Assistant Curator
Furniture, Textiles and Fashion Department
Victoria & Albert Museum"

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] That's fantastic! And how lovely of the Curator to come back to you so quickly. So, what do you now think about dating? Consensus has been 1890. We're now down to have fashionable the women captured in this photo were - on trend, or still wearing that style 5 years after it first appeared in London?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 
It still has to be 1890. Fashion lingers until the next fashion comes along.
I suppose the next fashion was wide-brimmed hats of 1900.
Some older people continue to wear the styles of their youth.
When I collected my Certificate of Apprenticeship in 1962, the boss was wearing a wing collar.
It was good of Lizzie Bisley to reply. I wonder if she has a nickname at the V&A?
